ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much in this class -- how to write concise responses to theory-heavy texts, how to sharpen the conceptual frameworks in my own research, how to write a solid research proposal, and how to conduct an academic workshop with my peers. This class has made me think about commemoration and the transmission of memory in much more nuanced ways, and I know that the insights and readings from this semester will continue to shape my academic path.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: incredibly helpful and constant feedback, many opportunities to write and engage with the readings before class, guided but wide-ranging seminar discussions, and a community of peers with similar academic interests. Weaknesses: this isn't a weakness, but just a heads up that I found this class to be by far the most conceptually challenging class that I have taken at Yale. I've learned so much and am very glad to have taken it, but I'd go in prepared to struggle to articulate yourself and to feel lost before or as the pieces start clicking.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students who are already curious about the politics of commemoration, memory, and preservation, especially if you're working on a senior essay, dissertation, or some other larger body of work about a specific topic that references these themes. The weekly reading load is very doable, but you should take this course only if you have time to write a weekly reading response and devote a significant amount of time and brainpower to the final research project.
Yes I would! It's a lot of work but very rewarding and I feel like I learnt how complicated memory can be.

Yes! This course is a wonderful opportunity to explore the field of memory studies while pursuing a specific topic of interest as well. The final research paper process is a valuable process and unique opportunity to piece together a high-level research paper with instructor and peer feedback along the way. All of the students come to the course with such diverse interests and insights into memory studies making for a really valuable, peer-based classroom learning environment.
